ZIEGLER: In 2006, you led a complexâ€”another very complex evaluation that produced a report entitled The Development Potential of Regional Programs: an Evaluation of World Bankâ€™s Support of Multi-country Operations [The Development Potential of Regional Programs: an Evaluation of World Bankâ€™s Support of Multi-country Operations. I argued that it would be good to know, even though the experience was limited, what the experience had been, what had worked well, when and why, with the aim of learning what the record might suggest about the potential development gains of scaling up World Bank assistance for multi-country regional projects and programs.

ZIEGLER: And an example would be?
GWIN: Well, a large and early example would be the CGIAR [Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research].
ZIEGLER: Yeah.
GWIN: Other more recent examples are the Water and Sanitation Program, and PEFA, which is Public Expenditure Financial Assessment. Essentially, these are programs that provide technical assistance.
ZIEGLER: Yeah.
GWIN: But the difference in the regional area is that the Bank engages in both partnership programs and lending operations. And regional investment lending is complicated because

ZIEGLER: Yes.
GWIN: These programs involved investment lending by the Bank. In addition, the Bank is engaged in regional partnership programs supported by multiple donors, and in which the Bank is one of a number of partners. It made the regional projects evaluation very interesting.
ZIEGLER: How did you proceed to implement this very complex evaluation?
GWIN: This wasn't complex in the way the other ones were, which were just unwieldy and hard to define and so forth. This was pretty straightforward. It was a matter of selecting. Four, demand and support is limited because of the complexities in arranging programs in ways that share benefit-to-cost equitably among countries. That's a complicated point. GWIN: We were talking about what makes a regional program successful, and there were a number of different points. A second one Iâ€Ÿll highlight is the importance of the governance arrangements. ZIEGLER: OED, originally?
GWIN: Yes.

ZIEGLER: Un-huh.
GWIN: What I have heard is that McNamara paid little attention to OED because it wasnâ€Ÿt what he wanted. He wanted something that would answer questions for him.
ZIEGLER: Right.
GWIN: We report to the Board, so management is under our microscope. So, of course, theyâ€Ÿre going to be defensive.

ZIEGLER: Did youâ€”the evaluation methods that you employed, did they evolve in any . . .

doc.abstracts: In January 2010, Catherine Gwin was interviewed on behalf of the World Bank Group Archives oral history program by Charles Ziegler. During her tenure at the Bank from 2001 to 2007, Mrs. Gwin worked in the following areas: in the operations evaluation department for corporate evaluation and methods as a lead evaluation officer (2001-2006) and for an independent evaluation group for corporate evaluation and methods as a lead evaluation officer (2006-2007). Her contributions to the World Bank include a paper titled "United States relations with the World Bank, 1945 to 1992", a book titled Investing in Women: Progress and Prospects for the World Bank, and also a report titled "The Development Potential of Regional Programs: An Evaluation of World Bank Support of Multi-country Operations" (2006). Her transcript concerns the roles and status of women within the World Bank.
